description: From Middle English sylveren, selverne, from Old English seolfren, from Proto-Germanic *silubrīnaz (“made of silver”); equivalent to silver +‎ -(e)n. Cognate with Dutch zilveren (“silvern”), German silbern (“silvern”).

entries.meaning: (literary) Made of silver; or resembling or characteristic of silver; silvery.
examples: I know a pool, where shadows fall / From fir-trees, melancholy tall, / That dream and quiver round the rim, / And in the molten centre swim, / Where taper tops do all unite / Bemirrored in its silvern light.
